qas.question: Who made the view of diplomatic drift popular?
What did A.W Kinglake make the British out to be?
Who believed Britain was following a strategy when trying to destroy Russian Navy?

context: This view of 'diplomatic drift' as the cause of the war was first popularised by <a0_0>A. W, Kinglake<a0_0/>, who portrayed the British <a1_0>as victims<a1_0/> of newspaper sensationalism and duplicitous French and Ottoman diplomacy. More recently, the historians <a2_0>Andrew Lambert and Winfried Baumgart<a2_0/> have argued that, first, Britain was following a geopolitical strategy in aiming to destroy a fledgling Russian Navy which might challenge the Royal Navy for control of the seas, and second that the war was a joint European response to a century of Russian expansion not just southwards but also into western Europe.
